On 8/22/06, Simon Chappell <simonpeterchappell@...> wrote:
>
>
> > 10=
0% code coverage is not just impossible to obtain and maintain, it's
> also=

> > deceptive and can make you think you are exercising your code in all
>=
 > possible ways.  Which is, of course, never true.
>
> Never say never. Yo=
u have dismissed an absolute statement with an
> absolute statement. That o=
nly works in political ad campaigns. (and
> rebuttals to absolute statement=
s :-)


Touch=E9.

Let's just say that getting a coverage tool to indicate =
100% is
close-to-impossible (and on a personal note, I think it's silly to =
strive
for that high anyway because you will hit a point of diminishing ret=
urn way
before).

On top of that, if you reach this elusive 100%, you're st=
ill not sure you
really have 100% code coverage (and most likely, you don't=
, because the
number of paths through your code is astronomical).

An examp=
le from one of my hobbies: target shooting with a .22 rifle. I
> find that =
when I use large targets (1 inch diameter bulls eye) I shoot
> at about upp=
er 80's% accuracy. When I shoot with smaller targets (half
> inch bulls eye=
), I shoot with lower 90's% accuracy. This seems
> counter-intuitive, but I=
've done it often enough to know that it's
> consistently true for me. The =
lesson that I have learned from this is
> that the small target seems more =
difficult and so I try harder and
> subsequently get a better result. The b=
igger target seems less of a
> challenge, so I relax a little and my scores=
 drop.


I like this metaphor.  There are other possible explanations, thou=
gh, but
your point is well taken.

-- 
C=E9dric
